docs.lead_paragraph: It is pick-'em odds on Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, when the Senate Finance Committee meets Tuesday to vote on health care legislation. Ms. Snowe, the only Republican who has expressed willingness to support the bill, has not offered any clues on whether she will vote for or against. Even Washington's most seasoned political bookmakers are not venturing a guess.

headline.main: A Preview of the Floor Fight

docs.abstract: Even most seasoned political oddsmakers are not venturing guess on where Sen Olympia J Snowe will land when Senate Finance Committee meets to vote on health care legislation; Snowe, only Republican who has expressed willingness to support bill, has not offered any clues on whether she will vote for or against; because Democrats hold 13-10 majority on panel, there is no question that bill is headed to Senate floor (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee had to backpedal over the weekend, canceling plans to run a television commercial that trumpeted the support of some big-name Republicans for a health care overhaul after one of them, former Senator Bob Dole, protested that the spot was misleading. But other Democratic allies were still using Mr. Dole's name. Such mentions could give political cover to wavering legislators to support an overhaul.
docs.abstract: Democratic National Committee cancels plans to run television ad trumpeting support of some prominent Republicans for health care overhaul after former Sen Bob Dole protests that spot was misleading; Dole says he objects to ad because he felt he was being used against his own party and because it undermined his goal of keeping Republicans at table to forge solution (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In September, President Obama promised $25 million to support state demonstration projects to evaluate strategies for tort reform -- an issue dear to many doctors who say that excessive medical malpractice awards and rising insurance premiums are significantly increasing health care costs. In fact, states have already experimented with some approaches. Here is a sampling:

docs.lead_paragraph: A proposed tax on high-cost, or ''Cadillac,'' health insurance plans has touched off a fierce clash between the Senate and the House as they wrestle over how to pay for legislation that would provide health benefits to millions of uninsured Americans. Supporters, including many senators, say that the tax is essential to tamping down medical spending and that over 10 years it would generate more than $200 billion, nearly a fourth of what is needed to pay for the legislation.

headline.main: CONGRESS SPLIT ON A HEALTH TAX ON COSTLY PLANS
